bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Wilton L. Halverson, November 21, 1952

div1.p: Hench suggests to Halverson that a representative of the American Public Health Association place one or two wreaths during the dedication ceremonies of Camp Lazear, or send a message if no one attends. If Halverson has not received an invitation, Hench would be glad to suggest discreetly that he be invited.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Wilton L. Halverson, November 21, 1952
div1.opener:
November 21, 1952
Dr. Wilton L. Halverson, President
American Public Health Association
760 Market Street
San Francisco, 2, California
My dear Doctor Halverson:
div1.p:
You may have heard that the Cuban Government has made a little park at
Walter Reed's Camp Lazear outside of Havana and are dedicating it to
the glories of Doctor Finlay, Major Reed and their colleagues on Decem-
ber 3, Finlay's birthday which is “Physicians' Day in Cuba.” Although
Doctor Finlay will receive perhaps the major share of honors, nonetheless
this is a very gracious gesture on the part of the Cubans for this is the
first time they have ever honored Major Reed. I understand they propose
to maintain the name Camp Lazear and that Reed's Building No. 1 will re-
tain its name also.

I believe that you and/or some of your associates will receive official
invitations to the affair, at least I hope so. The Surgeon General has
appointed General Paul H. Streit, Commanding General of Walter Reed
Hospital, as his official representative. The Mayo Foundation is sending
me as its representative. The ceremony will probably be a modest one in
view of the humble nature of Camp Lazear, but nevertheless it will be one
of real significance.

There seems to have been some delay in sending invitations from Cuba. This
was related to the uncertainty as to the date when the little memorial would
be dedicated. Already the date has been postponed at least once. If you
have not received an invitation, I would appreciate it if you would let me
know and I will discreetly make the proper suggestions at once. In view of
the outstanding contributions of Dr. Carlos Finlay and Walter Reed and his
colleagues to sanitation, I do believe that you and your associates would
be glad to know of this affair and, if possible, participate in it in some
way.

Doctor Halverson, I have suggested that the few Americans who attend the
ceremony should not go empty-handed but should make some friendly gesture.
Therefore the Mayo Foundation has authorized me to place a wreath under
the medallion of Doctor Finlay and it may be that The Surgeon General's
representative and/or the deans of the four or five medical schools from
which Doctor Finlay, Major Reed and the others received their degrees, may
present wreaths, or at least send wires expressing the interest and ap-
preciation of the American Medical profession in this gracious gesture by
which the Cuban Government and people are honoring not only Doctor Finlay
but Walter Reed and their American colleagues.

May I make this suggestion for what it is worth and you can act on it as
you see fit. If you should decide to send a wire or message, it could be
sent to Dr. Jose Andreu, El Ministro de Salubridad y Asistencia Social,
Havana, to Dr. Pedro Nogueira, Marti 219, Marianao, Havana, or to Dr.
Cesar Rodriguez Exposito, Secretary, Marti 219, Marianao, Havana. Should
you prefer to place one or two wreaths during the ceremony, I should be
glad to let you know what arrangements I am making along that line regarding
the wreath from the Mayo Foundation.
